greeting: New face in town, aren't you? My name's Hanni Aebi. Come, sit a spell, and tell me what brings you to our humble village.

start.text: New face in town, aren't you? My name's Hanni Aebi. Come, sit a spell, and tell me what brings you to our humble village.

options.text: I'm fine, thank you. Just passing through.
options.responseText: Hanni nods kindly. 'Safe travels then, dearie. May your path be clear.'

village_backstory.text: Oh, this village has seen many seasons. We're nestled right at the foot of the Whisperwind Peaks, you see. Long ago, they say ancient spirits dwelled there, protecting us from the creeping shadows of the Sunken City. It's quieter now, but the old ways linger. We will know the shadows are back if our young ones start disappearing. The shadows crave innocent minds. But so far, no missing children.

options.text: That's enough history for now. Can you help me?
Thank you for the stories. I should go.
options.responseText: Hanni smiles warmly. 'Anytime, dearie. Come back if you need a warm word or a helping hand.'

sunken_city_lore.text: The Sunken City... a tragic tale. It was once a grand kingdom, swallowed by the earth and sea in a single night. Some say it was a curse, others, a forgotten magic. Best not to dwell on such things too long; they tend to draw unwanted attention.

options.text: That's enough history for now. Can you help me?

options.responseText: Hanni nods, her expression thoughtful. 'Indeed. Some stories are best left untold.'

healing_offer.text: Oh, you poor thing. You look a bit rough. I've got some remedies. What do you need?

options.text: Try to keep up with Mornik's drinking.

Excuse yourself and try to find a room for the night.

options.text: Any advice on dealing with them?

You thank Mornik for his stories and head out.

wake_up_hangover.text: The morning sun is blinding. You groan, your head pounding like a blacksmith's hammer. You're not in a bed. You're lying on a pile of leaves, surrounded by trees. You're in the woods, and you have no idea how you got here. And you feel a bit worse for wear.
wake_up_hangover.responseText: A truly epic hangover. You take 3 damage from the ordeal. The tavern is nowhere in sight.

options.responseText: You shake your head, trying to clear the fog, and stumble forward, leaving the mystery of last night behind.

greeting: Ahoy there. I'm Man Francis. Some people call me Old Man Francis. Kind of Rude if you ask me but if the Pince-nez fits. I don't really wear glasses but, anyway, How is your day?

start.text: Ahoy there. I'm Man Francis. Some people call me Old Man Francis. Kind of Rude if you ask me but if the Pince-nez fits. I don't really wear glasses but, anyway, How is your day?

lesson_1.text: 'Oh yeah I can do that. First, you need a good spot. Not too deep, not too shallow. Got it?'

options.text: This is too complicated. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis sighs. 'Some folks just ain't cut out for it.'

lesson_2.text: 'Next, the bait. Worms, crickets, maybe a shiny lure. Maybe even some goblin slime. Depends on what yer after. Understand?'

options.text: I'm losing patience. I give up.

lesson_3.text: 'Then, the cast. A smooth, gentle flick of the wrist. Not too hard, not too soft. But not too not not hard or soft. Basically in the middle. Think you can do it?'

options.text: This is harder than it looks. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis chuckles. 'Practice makes perfect. Or in this case, practice makes a person give up.'

lesson_4.text: 'Now, the waiting game. That's where most folks fail. Just watch for any action on the line or the bobber. Got the patience for it?'

options.text: This is boring. I give up.

options.text: I am not sure I am rea-

lesson_6.text: 'The current, now. She's a tricky beast. Learn to cast with it, not against it. It'll take your bait right where the fish are hiding. Understand the flow?'

options.text: I'm not sure I am following your logi-'
This is getting too deep. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis shakes his head. 'The river don't wait for no one.'

lesson_7.text: 'Weather signs. A storm brewin', fish go deep. A gentle drizzle, they might come up. Look to the sky, and listen to the air. What do you see?'

options.text: I see a lot of water and some clouds in the sky. I see you. I smell you, too.

lesson_8.text: 'The art of chumming. A little bit of food, scattered just so, can bring 'em right to you. Don't overdo it, though, or they'll be full. Got the knack?'

options.text: I don't want to waste bait. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis sighs. 'Sometimes you gotta give a little to get a lot.'

lesson_10.text: 'It's important to understand the yank of the fish. Sometimes the fish will be a big ol' goofball and that means you have to put in what the fish is hitting you with. You have to feel it.

options.text: I'll focus on the feel. Do you have any beer to go with this?

options.responseText: Old Man Francis chuckles. 'Then ye'll miss the subtle whispers.'

lesson_11.text: 'I don't drink. Choosing your hook size. Too big, they won't bite. Too small, they'll get away. It's a delicate balance. Think you can pick the right one?'

options.text: This is too much detail. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis shrugs. 'The details make the difference.'

lesson_12.text: 'The art of the retrieve. Slow, steady, or wobbling? Depends on the fish, depends on the lure. Every retrieve tells a story. What's your story?'

options.text: I'm on an adventure. What is your story?
I'm just reeling. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francisr sighs. 'Then ye'll only catch the lazy ones.'
Old Man Francis nods. 'Some lessons are learned only through waiting and getting to know your fellow fisherman.'

lesson_14.text: 'Anyway, the moon's phases. Some say a full moon brings the fish out, others say it drives 'em deep. It's a mystery, but one worth pondering. What do you think?'

options.text: I could see a full moon doing something to a fish, I suppose.
I'm not an astrologer. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis chuckles. 'The sky holds many secrets, not just for fish.'

lesson_15.text: 'Understanding the fish's natural habitat. Rocks, weeds, sunken logs... they all provide cover. Cast near 'em, but not in 'em.'

options.text: I keep getting snagged. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis sighs. 'The best spots are often the trickiest.'

lesson_16.text: 'Yes, I am sure. The sound of the water. A gentle lapping, a rushing stream... different sounds mean different things. Listen closely. What do you hear?'

options.text: I hear you, to be quite honest.
It's just noise to me. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis shakes his head. 'The sea sings a song, if you listen.'

lesson_17.text: 'The importance of camouflage. Your shadow, your bright clothes... they can spook the fish. Blend in with nature.'

options.text: Got it. I won't wear my neon colored scarf while fishing.
I like my bright clothes. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis shrugs. 'Then you'll be seen, and the fish will flee.'

lesson_18.text: 'Not to get too philosophic but this is what it's all about. The wash of the waves, the peaceful breeze, the potential fish to be caught, eating the bait when no one is looking...'

options.text: Eating bait is pretty gross. I give up.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis sighs. 'Suit yourself.'

lesson_19.text: 'Wait... I think you have something. I think you have something.'

options.text: Reel in the fish using the lessons you have learned.
Throw your fishing pole into the sea.
options.responseText: Old Man Francis smiles sadly. 'Why did you do that?'

lesson_20.text: 'You got it. Thats the biggest fish I have seen in a long while. I bet that fish ages well with age.'

options.text: Receive the Fish of Eternal Enlightenment
options.responseText: You receive The Fish of Eternal Enlightenment. It shimmers with ancient power.

name: The Fallen Tree
greeting: A quiet walk through the woods is shattered by a desperate scream for help. You follow the sound, finding a person pinned beneath a large, fallen tree. The person is struggling, their face a mask of pain. Their voice is weak, pleading for you to help them.

start.text: A quiet walk through the woods is shattered by a desperate scream for help. You follow the sound, finding a person pinned beneath a large, fallen tree. The person is struggling, their face a mask of pain. Their voice is weak, pleading for you to help them.

options.text: Attempt to lift the tree off the person.
Ask the person for their name.
Walk away as if you didn't hear anything at all.
options.responseText: You turn and walk away, the scream fading behind you. Best not to get involved.

kidnapped_start.text: As you get closer, you feel a sharp pain on the back of your head. The lights go out, and your consciousness drifts away.

dream_sequence.text: You dream of a time long ago, safe and sound at your parents' old peat-covered lakehouse. You are young again, chasing squirrels and helping your father chop wood by the shore. Everything is calm. You are safe. You are safe.

wakeup.text: You wake up with a jolt, a dull ache throbbing in your head. You are tied to a chair with ropes in a dimly lit, underground bunker. A closed metal door sits opposite you. At a nearby table, a man is sitting, calmly cutting up an apple with a knife and eating the pieces.

options.text: Scream, 'Where am I?! Who are you?!'
Offer your gold to be released.
Say nothing and stare at the man.

wakeup_stand.text: You strain against the ropes, attempting to stand, but the chair topples over. The man sighs, gets up, and without a word, rights the chair and you back up straight.

wakeup_gold.text: The man doesn't even look up from his apple. 'Oh, don't worry,' he says, 'we plan on stealing everything from you no matter how this turns out.'

wakeup_stare.text: You stare at the man. The man continues to stare at his apple, taking another bite.

dialogue_route.text: The man stops cutting his apple, puts the knife on the table, and meets your gaze. 'Me? I'm nobody. You? You're a ransom toward a big payday.'

dialogue_route_2.text: 'We have been following you,' he says, a small smile playing on his lips. 'We've seen you talk to Lords and Kings on your journey. You are definitely somebody.'

dialogue_route_3.text: 'You mean your Kings and noblepeople will pay us for this?' he replies with a sneer.

choke_event.text: The man laughs, puts a piece of apple in his mouth, starts chewing, and stands up. He walks over to you, pointing the knife at your throat. With a mouth full of apple, he says, 'Yeah... very funny. I'm not the one tied u-' He suddenly starts choking, grabbing his throat. He falls down, flailing on the ground, and soon enough, the life leaves his body. His knife clatters to the floor.

options.text: Fall on the ground near the knife to cut your ropes free.

freedom_options.text: After a struggle, you manage to cut yourself free. You stand up, your legs still a little unsteady, and look around the bunker. The metal door is your only way out.

open_door.text: You open the metal door, revealing a small hallway. You can go left or right.

go_left.text: You hear a loud clanking of ale glasses and loud, drunken voices through a closed door on the left.

options.text: Kick the door down and get your revenge for ruining a nice day.
options.responseText: You smash the door off its hinges, revealing a room full of rowdy, startled kidnappers. They all turn to face you.

options.text: Turn around and go right instead.

go_right.text: You see a set of stairs leading up to a cellar door.

options.text: Turn around and go the other way.

options.responseText: You carefully open the cellar door and slip outside, into the cool night air. You are free.
